isis.stitle: ELECTRICAL SYSTEM TROUBLESHOOTING GUIDE / 2000 4000 and 8000 MODELS BUILT OCTOBER 1, 1998 AND AFTER - ALLISON WT TRANSMISSION WITH WTEC III ELECTRONIC CONTROLS - TROUBLESHOOTING - TROUBLESHOOTING WITH DIAGNOSTIC CODES

svcprocinfo.para: The tests in this section are written to be performed by reading the diagnostic codes using the shift selector and the Fluke 88 multimeter. In many cases an electronic service tool can be used for reading the codes and performing some system diagnostics if the proper software is available. Note that if battery power is not present at the ECU, the electronic service tool will not be able to read the codes or perform other diagnostics.

When beginning the troubleshooting process, always check for ACTIVE diagnostic codes first. The codes listed in this service section are only those codes that are likely to be involved with International-installed components and harnesses.For a full listing of diagnostic codes, refer to the Allison WT Service Manual and WTEC III Controls and General Information Manual.

important.para: Low transmission oil levels, low battery power, battery power interruptions and intermittent ground connections can cause many diagnostic codes to be registered.

step1.para: Perform test ECU and Shift Selector Power and Ground Circuits, Table 3. Look carefully for (and correct) conditions that can cause intermittent conditions such as:

step2.para: Loose, dirty, corroded or painted connections.
Check related relays and fuses for overheating or open condition.

svcsubproc.title: Main Code 13 Sub Code 12, 13, or 23 - ECU Input Voltage
svcsubproc.para: This code means the ECU has detected either a high, medium low, or low battery input voltage. The ECU monitors battery voltage input levels to its connector (632)/pins 136 and 136A, and shift selector (420)/pin R. LOW voltage is considered less than 8 volts, medium low voltage is considered 10 volts, and HIGH voltage is considered more than 32 volts. Common causes for this code are usually vehicle wiring conditions, vehicle charging system and batteries, or poor ground conditions.

note.para: The ECU turns OFF when voltage drops to approximately 7.0 volts.

svcsubproc.para: Perform test ECU and Shift Selector Power and Ground Circuits, Table 3.

svcsubproc.title: Main Code 23 Sub Code 12 or 16
svcsubproc.para: This code indicates a fault with the shift selector assembly or the harnesses that connect it to the ECU.

step1.para: Clear active codes as explained in Clearing Diagnostic Code Indicator. If code 23 XX re-occurs, go to step 2.
Check for poor connections at connectors (420) and (634).
Go to test Shift Selector Harness Circuitry, Table 5.
If no problem found with circuitry have Allison dealer diagnose and replace selector if necessary.

svcsubproc.title: Main Code 26 Sub Code 00 or 11
svcsubproc.para: This code indicates that the ECU has not detected either a throttle source or an engine coolant temperature source.

step1.para: When code 26 00 is logged and the throttle signal is being supplied via the J1587 communications link, refer to code 66 00 for troubleshooting.
When code 26 11 is logged and the engine coolant temperature is being supplied via the J1587 communications link, refer to code 66 00 for troubleshooting.

svcsubproc.title: Main Code 35 Sub Code 00 or 16 - Power Interruption
svcsubproc.para: This code indicates that the ECU detected a complete battery power loss before the ignition was turned off. This code cannot be displayed as an active code, but will be displayed only after power is restored.
When this happens, the ECU is not able to save the current operating parameters in memory before turning itself off.

step1.para: On vehicles equipped with a master switch, turning off the master switch before turning off the ignition switch can cause this code.
If improper switch sequencing is not the cause, check ECU power and ground circuits (see test ECU and Shift Selector Power and Ground Circuits, Table 3).
If all system power and ground connections are satisfactory and problem persists, have Allison dealer diagnose and replace ECU if necessary.

svcsubproc.title: Main Code 62 Sub Code 32 or 33
svcsubproc.para: This code indicates that the engine coolant temperature sensor or circuit has failed. Code 62 32 reports that the reading is below operational values. Code 62 33 reports that the leading is above operations values.

step1.para: If code 66 11 is present refer to test J1708 Communications Link, Table 4.
Refer to engine troubleshooting guide to diagnose problem with coolant temperature sensor or circuits to engine ECM if code 66 11 is not present.

svcsubproc.title: Main Code 66 Sub Code 00 or 11
svcsubproc.para: This code indicates that the Allison ECU detects a problem getting information over the J1708 (Serial Communications Interface) data link.
Code 66 00 reports that the link is not functioning.
Code 66 11 reports that the Allison ECU cannot find a source for the engine coolant temperature.
These codes can also be set if the J1939 communications link communications fail.

step1.para: Use an electronic service tool to check for throttle and coolant temperature signals. If no data communications are present refer to test J1708 Communications Link, Table 4. If problem not found, go to step 2.
Using the engine warning lights or electronic service tool check for engine throttle or coolant temperature fault codes, If no problem found, go to step 3.
